measure: A theoretically derived measure from a three‐period stochastic overlapping‐generations model

title: Income Inequality, Mobility, and the Welfare State: A Political Economy Model
cited_by: https://openalex.org/W2343778547, https://openalex.org/W1480708160
measure: No standard empirical measure is used; rather, the paper employs a three‐period stochastic overlapping generations model to structurally analyze mobility and its political equilibrium implications.

cited_by: https://openalex.org/W4393244952, https://openalex.org/W4399529338, https://openalex.org/W4312204683

title: Income Mobility in the United States
cited_by: https://openalex.org/W2550399851
measure: Intergenerational Elasticity (IGE) or a similar regression‐based coefficient capturing the association between youth standard of living and adult income

title: More Educated, Less Mobile? Diverging Trends in Income and Education Mobility in Chile and Peru
cited_by: https://openalex.org/W4312514773, https://openalex.org/W3004654623, https://openalex.org/W4312921721, https://openalex.org/W3095116300
measure: The paper employs a regression‐based measure—namely, the Intergenerational Elasticity (IGE) for income persistence (with coefficients between 0.63–0.76)—as well as an absolute mobility measure that reports upward mobility probabilities (e.g. the chances of moving from no formal education to higher education, 46% in Peru vs. 20% in Chile).

This collection of indicators does not neatly fall into one of the standard categories, so it is best classified as ‘Others.’

measure: The paper does not report a canonical intergenerational mobility measure such as an intergenerational elasticity or a rank‐based mobility rate. Instead, it uses naturally occurring quasi‐experiments—a set of counterfactual simulations on firm entry and productivity in the cartel chapters and, crucially, a causal displacement design based on forced relocation—to estimate treatment effects on long‐term and intergenerational outcomes (education, mortality, income, and crime).

title: Public pensions and the intergenerational politics of aging societies
cited_by: https://openalex.org/W4321607782, https://openalex.org/W4298082494, https://openalex.org/W4298305823
measure: The paper does not use a standard off‐the-shelf mobility measure (like IGE, rank‐based slopes, or transition probabilities) but rather develops a structural parameter of income mobility within a cross‐national overlapping generations model. This can be seen as a model‐generated (or structural) income mobility parameter, which does not neatly fall into one of the standard categories.

measure: The paper employs two kinds of mobility statistics. On one hand, it reports absolute mobility rates – that is, total, upward, downward, and outflow mobility rates calculated from partial parent–child transition tables (which fall under absolute mobility measures, category 4). On the other hand, it estimates a net grandparent–grandchild association summarized by a single uniform parameter expressed as odds ratios (a regression‐based measure, category 1).

title: The Emergence of Inequality and Hierarchy: A Network Explanation
cited_by: https://openalex.org/W2165038468, https://openalex.org/W3112478890, https://openalex.org/W3110947645
measure: The paper does not use a standard mobility measure but instead develops a theoretical model that characterizes equilibrium network structures. In this model, stability is determined by coalitions (restricted by a network distance k), intermediation decay in network benefits, and the degree of intergenerational transmission of wealth. Thus, the measure falls under ‘Others’ as it is a network‐equilibrium based approach rather than one of the conventional mobility measures.

title: The Evolution of Social Mobility: Norway Over the 20th Century
cited_by: https://openalex.org/W2279724997, https://openalex.org/W3123545316, https://openalex.org/W3121288668, https://openalex.org/W2960419415, https://openalex.org/W2941051445, https://openalex.org/W3121325423
measure: The paper uses multiple measures. For instance, the intergenerational income elasticity (IGE) is a regression‐based measure (1); the association between fathers’ and sons’ income percentiles is a rank‐based measure (2); and the brother correlations do not squarely fall into any of the listed groups, so they are best viewed as an other measure (8).

title: Occupation, Income, Education and Modernization among the Horijon Community of Bangladesh: A Sociological Profile
measure: The paper does not specify a well‐known mobility measure. Instead, it uses a subjective approach to gauge modernity levels based on behavioral perspectives, along with data from social surveys and observations. This does not fall into the standard categories such as regression‐based measures (e.g., intergenerational elasticity) or rank‐based measures, so it is categorized under 'Others'.

measure: The paper reviews traditional occupation‐based measures (using social position indicators derived from an individual’s occupation, as well as related measures like household income mobility, job displacement, union dissolution, and poverty dynamics) and then proposes an alternative household‐level measure that gauges the rate of mobility‐generating events driven by institutional incentives and social insurance. These measures do not neatly fall into the standard categories.
